It  is  a  well-founded  principle  of  criminal  law  that  when  a  party  prefers  a
criminal  charge  against  an  accused,  it  is  the  party  making  the  same  must
prove  its  case  beyond  a  reasonable  doubt,  and  the  accused  can  even  remain
silent.
It has been held in the case of James Silva vs The Republic of Sri Lanka
1980 (2) SLR page 167 that “ It is a grave error of law for a trial judge to
direct himself that he must examine the tenability and truthfulness of the
evidence of the defense in the light of the prosecution case. Our criminal
law  postulates  a  fundamental  presumption  of  legal  innocence  of  every
accused till the contrary is proved. This is rooted in the principle of legal
inviolability

As  such,  in  the  instant  matter  we  find  that  the  trial  judge  in  considering  the
evidence of the defense after deciding that the prosecution has proved its case
beyond a reasonable has violated a basic principle of criminal law.
Furthermore, the defense put forward by the appellant at the time of the  trial
has  been  put  to  all  the  prosecution  witnesses  in  cross  examination  and  the
prosecution had not been able to challenge the said evidence.
As  such,  we  find  that  the  defense  of  the  appellant  at  the  trial  had  been
consistent and cogent and it has created a reasonable doubt in the case for the
prosecution which has already been contradicted on vital matters as discussed
above.
Hence, we find that the trial judge had not considered the merits of the case in
the manner prescribed by law.
